column1: Beni Suef (Arabic: بني سويف‎ Baniswēf) is the capital city of the Beni Suef Governorate in Egypt. An important agricultural trade centre on the west bank of the Nile River
column2: the city is located 110 km (70 miles) south of Cairo.

column1: The modern name of the town is a corruption of its original name Manfiswayh (Arabic: منفسويه‎) which itself comes from a Coptic toponymic construction ⲡ-ⲙⲁ-ⲛ-... ("the place of...") but its exact etymology is unknown.
From the early Pharaonic era to the Roman period
column2: the area was home to the city of Heracleopolis
column3: 10 miles west of the modern city. which also served as the capital of Lower and Middle Egypt during the 9th and 10th dynasties. The modern city rose to prominence during the Middle Ages
column4: when it was renowned for its linen manufacturing
column5: which continues to the present day through the city's carpet making and cotton spinning industries. Beni Suef became the chief town of the second province of Upper Egypt during the reign of Muhammad Ali in the 19th Century.

column1: The total area of the governorate is 1
column3: and it is divided into six governorates. It is bordered to the north by Giza governorate and Helwan
column5: to the east by the Red Sea governorate
column6: to the west by Fayoum governorate
column7: and to the south by Minya governorate. This region connects the north of Egypt to the south
column8: and the east to the west
column9: and this identity of centrality has formed the population
column11: and economic characters of the region. The geographical proximity to vital governorates such as Cairo and Giza is significant
column12: and the governorates of the Red Sea
column14: Fayoum and Ismailia tourist areas all act as markets for the industrial products made in Beni Suef.

column1: Beni Suef has a hot desert climate (BWh) in Köppen-Geiger classification
column2: as does all of Egypt. It has very hot summers and warm winters with cool nights.

column1: A train accident in 1995 near Beni Suef left 75 people dead.
